Award.AwardTitle: DIANA, an Underground Accelerator Facility for Nuclear Astrophysics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will enable continuation of research and development of plans for an underground accelerator laboratory that would address fundamental questions in nuclear astrophysics like understanding the origin of the elements and the chemical evolution of the universe. The goal is to eventually address three long-standing fundamental problems in nuclear astrophysics: solar neutrino sources and the core metallicity of the sun; carbon-based nucleosynthesis; and neutron sources for the production of trans-iron elements in stars. Each of these processes requires precise measurements of very low-energy nuclear cross sections. However, because of the small cross-sections and large radiation backgrounds in the typical laboratory environment, the use of underground-based low-energy accelerator facilities is required to advance our knowledge of low energy stellar reactions. The Dual Ion Accelerator for Nuclear Astrophysics (DIANA) is a proposed next generation underground accelerator laboratory providing enhanced capabilities in terms of substantially higher ion beam intensity, different ion species, and broader energy range than those at current facilities. It would enable measurements of solar burning cross-sections at lower energies with higher precision and enhance our knowledge of more complex reaction mechanisms during late stellar burning. This award provides support for research and development, feasibility studies of underground sites, and project development and definition so that the DIANA team can further advance the design activities and deliver reliable cost and schedule estimates. This work builds upon the conceptual design that was developed for the Homestake Mine in South Dakota.

If DIANA is eventually built, the facility will host a large number of graduate student and postdoctoral researchers and users, contributing to training professionals in the areas of radiation physics and nuclear technologies, which are essential for the national needs in medicine, energy production, defense, industry, and government. An outreach program will be developed in collaboration with the Joint Institute of Nuclear Astrophysics (JINA). It will take advantage of the opportunities offered by an underground location and will be organized in coordination with local colleges and outreach organizations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project was the design of an US based underground accelerator laboratory DIANA (Dual Ion Accelerator for Nuclear Astrophysics) consisting of two independent accelerator components to cover the wide energy range of particles at quiescent and explosive stellar burning processes. The purpose of such a facility is to measure low energy nuclear reactions that drive stellar evolution and the nucleosynthesis of the light elements in stars. The reactions are extremely weak, which warrants the long life-time of stars. For this reason a reliable measurement of reaction products is extremely difficult because of the large cosmic ray induced background radiation on the surface of our Earth. To measure the weak radiation induced by nuclear reactions at energies comparable to the interior of our sun or other stars requires moving accelerator laboratories into a deep underground mine were the cosmic radiation is absorbed by several thousand feet of rock. The development of such a facility is being recommended by the National Research Council (NRC) of the National Academies and by the Nuclear Science Advisory Committee (NSAC) to DOE and NSF.

Special focus for this part of the project was the test of the underground conditions and the technical requirements for the feasibility of the project. The design was successfully completed and a design report submitted to the National Science Foundation. The costs for a full project that could address all questions in the field are high.  In addition to the basic design new detector techniques have been developed and the level of background radiation was tested at different underground locations in the US and in Europe. A pilot facility CASPAR (Compact Accelerator System for Performing Astrophysical Research) has been constructed, primarily from private funding at the 4850 ft level of Sanford Underground Research Facility (SURF) at Homestake Mine in South Dakota. The goal was to develop a first suite of experiments on a low-cost basis and to provide a new learning and training instrument for the nuclear astrophysics community. The safety and risk analysis of this deep underground accelerator facility have been completed and are approved. The project is completed and first experiments have been scheduled for spring 2016.
